2-1-buydown-calculator.subtitle: Calculate the cost and monthly payment savings of a 2-1 temporary buydown

faq.question: What is a 2-1 buydown?
faq.answer: A 2-1 buydown is a temporary interest rate reduction where the rate is 2% lower than the note rate in year one, 1% lower in year two, and returns to the full note rate from year three onward.

faq.question: Who pays for a 2-1 buydown?
faq.answer: Typically the seller, builder, or lender pays for the buydown as a concession. The funds are placed in an escrow account and used to subsidize the borrower's payments.

faq.question: How much does a 2-1 buydown cost?
faq.answer: The cost equals the sum of the payment differences over the first two years. For a $400,000 loan at 7%, a 2-1 buydown typically costs around $8,000-$12,000.

faq.question: Is a 2-1 buydown worth it?
faq.answer: A 2-1 buydown can be worth it if you expect rates to drop and plan to refinance, or if you need lower initial payments to qualify for the loan.

3-2-1-buydown-calculator.subtitle: Calculate the cost and savings of a 3-2-1 temporary buydown over three years

faq.question: What is a 3-2-1 buydown?
faq.answer: A 3-2-1 buydown reduces your interest rate by 3% in year one, 2% in year two, 1% in year three, then reverts to the full note rate from year four.

faq.question: How much does a 3-2-1 buydown cost?
faq.answer: A 3-2-1 buydown costs more than a 2-1 because it covers three years of reduced payments. For a $400,000 loan at 7%, expect to pay $15,000-$20,000.

1-0-buydown-calculator.subtitle: Calculate the cost and first-year savings of a 1-0 temporary buydown

faq.question: What is a 1-0 buydown?
faq.answer: A 1-0 buydown reduces your interest rate by 1% for the first year only, then returns to the full note rate from year two onward.

faq.question: When is a 1-0 buydown a good choice?
faq.answer: A 1-0 buydown is ideal when you want lower initial payments but don't need a large rate reduction. It's the most affordable buydown option.

faq.question: How is the buydown cost calculated?
faq.answer: The buydown cost is the sum of all payment differences between the reduced rate and the note rate during the buydown period.

faq.question: What is a buydown subsidy?
faq.answer: A buydown subsidy is the amount of money needed to fund the temporary rate reduction. It's typically paid by the seller or builder as a concession.

faq.question: Should I use seller concessions for a buydown or closing costs?
faq.answer: It depends on your situation. A buydown lowers your monthly payment for 1-3 years, while closing cost credits reduce your upfront cash needed.

discount-points-break-even.subtitle: Calculate how many months until your discount points pay for themselves

faq.question: What are discount points?
faq.answer: Discount points are upfront fees paid to the lender to reduce your interest rate. One point equals 1% of the loan amount and typically reduces the rate by 0.25%.

faq.question: How do I calculate the break-even point?
faq.answer: Divide the cost of the points by the monthly savings. The result is the number of months needed to recoup your investment.

faq.question: Should I buy discount points?
faq.answer: Buy points if you plan to stay in the home longer than the break-even period and have extra cash at closing.

faq.question: What is a discount point?
faq.answer: A discount point is an upfront fee equal to 1% of your loan amount. Paying points reduces your interest rate, typically by 0.25% per point.

faq.question: How do I calculate discount points?
faq.answer: Multiply your loan amount by the number of points. For example, 1 point on a $400,000 loan costs $4,000.

faq.question: Are discount points worth buying?
faq.answer: Points are worth it if you'll keep the loan long enough to recoup the upfront cost through monthly savings. Calculate your break-even period to decide.

faq.question: How many points can I buy?
faq.answer: Most lenders allow up to 3-4 points, though some may offer more. There's typically a point of diminishing returns after 2-3 points.

faq.question: What is a rate lock fee?
faq.answer: A rate lock fee is what lenders charge to guarantee your interest rate for a specific period. Longer lock periods typically cost more.

faq.question: How long should I lock my rate?
faq.answer: Lock for as long as you need to close. Most purchases need 30-45 days, while refinances may need 15-30 days.

faq.question: How much does a rate lock extension cost?
faq.answer: Extension fees typically range from 0.125% to 0.375% of the loan amount per week, depending on the lender and market conditions.

faq.question: What is a float down option?
faq.answer: A float down option lets you reduce your locked rate if market rates drop before closing. It typically costs 0.25% to 0.50% of the loan amount.

faq.question: When is a float down worth it?
faq.answer: A float down is worth it if you expect significant rate drops and the savings exceed the upfront fee over your planned ownership period.

faq.question: What are typical closing costs?
faq.answer: Closing costs typically range from 2% to 5% of the loan amount. They include lender fees, title insurance, appraisal, and prepaid items like taxes and insurance.

faq.question: Who pays closing costs?
faq.answer: Buyers typically pay most closing costs, but sellers often contribute through concessions. Some costs can be rolled into the loan.

faq.question: What is cash to close?
faq.answer: Cash to close is the total amount you need to bring to the closing table. It includes your down payment, closing costs, prepaid items, minus any credits.

faq.question: Can I reduce my cash to close?
faq.answer: Yes, through seller concessions, lender credits, gift funds, or by choosing a low or no down payment loan program.

faq.question: What are common builder incentives?
faq.answer: Builders often offer incentives like closing cost credits, rate buydowns, free upgrades, or HOA fee coverage to move inventory. These can range from 2-6% of the purchase price.

faq.question: Can I use builder incentives for a buydown?
faq.answer: Yes! Builder incentives can fund a 2-1 or 3-2-1 buydown, giving you lower payments for the first few years of homeownership.

faq.question: What's the difference between temporary and permanent buydowns?
faq.answer: Temporary buydowns reduce your rate for 1-3 years, then revert to the note rate. Permanent buydowns (discount points) reduce your rate for the entire loan term.

faq.question: What's the difference between PMI and MIP?
faq.answer: PMI (Private Mortgage Insurance) is for conventional loans with less than 20% down. MIP (Mortgage Insurance Premium) is required on all FHA loans regardless of down payment.

faq.question: How can I remove mortgage insurance?
faq.answer: For conventional loans, PMI can be removed at 80% LTV. For FHA loans taken after 2013, MIP stays for the life of the loan unless you put 10%+ down (then it drops off after 11 years).

faq.question: What is payment shock?
faq.answer: Payment shock is the sudden increase in your monthly payment when an adjustable-rate mortgage (ARM) resets to a higher rate after the initial fixed period.

faq.question: How can I avoid payment shock?
faq.answer: You can refinance to a fixed-rate loan before your ARM adjusts, make extra principal payments to reduce the balance, or budget for the higher payment.

faq.question: What is a good break-even period for mortgage points?
faq.answer: Generally, a break-even period of 3-5 years is considered good. If you plan to stay in the home longer than the break-even period, buying points is likely worth it.

faq.answer: Discount Points Cost = Loan Amount × Points Percentage. For example, 1 point on a $400,000 loan = $400,000 × 1% = $4,000.

faq.question: How much does 1 discount point reduce the rate?
faq.answer: Typically, 1 discount point reduces your interest rate by 0.25%, though this varies by lender and market conditions.

faq.answer: 3 points on a $400,000 mortgage costs $12,000 ($400,000 × 3%). This typically reduces your rate by about 0.75%.

faq.question: Is buying 3 points worth it?
faq.answer: It depends on how long you plan to keep the loan. With 3 points, your break-even period is longer, but lifetime savings are greater if you stay 7+ years.

faq.question: Who typically pays for a 3-2-1 buydown?

faq.answer: Points Cost = Loan Amount × (Points ÷ 100). The break-even formula is: Points Cost ÷ Monthly Savings = Break-Even Months.

faq.answer: A buydown temporarily reduces your rate for 1-3 years, then reverts to the note rate. Points permanently reduce your rate for the life of the loan.

faq.question: Which is better: buydown or points?
faq.answer: Buydowns are better if you expect to refinance soon. Points are better if you'll keep the loan long-term (past the break-even point).

faq.question: What are lender credits?
faq.answer: Lender credits are money the lender gives you toward closing costs in exchange for accepting a higher interest rate.

faq.question: When should I take lender credits?
faq.answer: Take lender credits if you're short on cash for closing, plan to sell or refinance within a few years, or want to minimize upfront costs.

faq.question: What does it mean to float your rate?
faq.answer: Floating means not locking your rate, betting that rates will drop before you close. If rates rise instead, you'll pay more.

faq.question: When should I lock my rate?
faq.answer: Lock when you're comfortable with the rate and can close within the lock period. In volatile markets, locking provides certainty.

faq.question: What if rates drop after I lock?
faq.answer: Some lenders offer float-down options or will renegotiate. Otherwise, you're locked at your original rate.

faq.question: What's the main difference between FHA and conventional loans?
faq.answer: FHA loans have lower credit score requirements and smaller down payments, but require mortgage insurance for the life of the loan. Conventional loans have stricter requirements but PMI can be removed at 80% LTV.

faq.question: Is a 15-year mortgage better than 30-year?
faq.answer: A 15-year mortgage saves significant interest and builds equity faster, but has higher monthly payments. Choose based on your budget and goals.

faq.answer: ARMs can be good if you plan to sell or refinance before the rate adjusts, or if you expect rates to drop in the future.

faq.question: When is refinancing worth it?
faq.answer: Refinancing is typically worth it if you can lower your rate by at least 0.5-1%, plan to stay long enough to recoup costs, and your credit and equity qualify you for good terms.

2-1-vs-3-2-1-buydown.subtitle: Compare the cost and savings of each temporary buydown option

faq.question: Which buydown costs more?
faq.answer: A 3-2-1 buydown costs more because it covers three years of reduced payments instead of two. Expect to pay roughly double the cost of a 2-1 buydown.

faq.question: Which buydown saves more in year one?
faq.answer: The 3-2-1 buydown saves more in year one because the rate is reduced by 3% instead of 2%.

buydown-vs-price-reduction.subtitle: Should you use seller credits for a buydown or negotiate a lower price?

faq.question: When is a buydown better than a price reduction?
faq.answer: A buydown is often better when you need lower monthly payments to qualify or when you expect to refinance within 2-3 years. The cash flow benefit is immediate.

buydown-vs-seller-credit.subtitle: How should you use seller concessions - lower payments or lower cash to close?

faq.question: Should I use seller credits for buydown or closing costs?
faq.answer: If you have enough cash for closing but want lower payments, choose a buydown. If you're cash-strapped and need help with upfront costs, use credits for closing costs.

points-vs-refinance-later.subtitle: Should you pay for a lower rate now or wait for rates to drop?

faq.question: When is buying points better than waiting to refinance?
faq.answer: Buying points is better when you're uncertain if rates will drop, want guaranteed savings, or plan to hold the loan long-term beyond the break-even point.

apr-vs-interest-rate.h1: APR vs Interest Rate: What's the Difference?
apr-vs-interest-rate.subtitle: Learn which rate to focus on when comparing mortgage offers

faq.question: Should I compare APR or interest rate?
faq.answer: Use APR when comparing loan offers from different lenders as it includes fees. Use interest rate when calculating your actual monthly payment.

faq.question: Why is APR higher than interest rate?
faq.answer: APR includes the interest rate plus other loan costs like origination fees, points, and mortgage insurance, spread over the loan term.

is-2-1-buydown-worth-it.title: Is a 2-1 Buydown Worth It?
is-2-1-buydown-worth-it.metaTitle: Is a 2-1 Buydown Worth It? | Decision Calculator & Analysis
is-2-1-buydown-worth-it.metaDescription: Find out if a 2-1 buydown makes sense for your situation. Compare scenarios and see when a 2-1 buydown is smart vs when to skip it.
is-2-1-buydown-worth-it.subtitle: Decision tool to help you determine if a 2-1 buydown fits your situation

faq.question: When is a 2-1 buydown worth it?
faq.answer: A 2-1 buydown is worth it when: (1) the seller/builder pays for it, (2) you expect to refinance in 2-3 years as rates drop, (3) you need lower initial payments to qualify, or (4) you expect income growth.

faq.question: When should I skip a 2-1 buydown?
faq.answer: Skip the buydown if: (1) you're paying for it yourself and could use that money better elsewhere, (2) you're unsure you can handle the full payment in year 3, or (3) you're getting a better deal on price reduction.

discount-points-vs-temporary-buydown.title: Discount Points vs Temporary Buydown
discount-points-vs-temporary-buydown.metaTitle: Discount Points vs Temporary Buydown | Which is Better?
discount-points-vs-temporary-buydown.metaDescription: Compare discount points vs temporary buydown strategies. See which option saves more based on your timeline and goals.
discount-points-vs-temporary-buydown.subtitle: Compare permanent rate reduction vs temporary lower payments

faq.question: What's the difference between points and a buydown?
faq.answer: Discount points permanently reduce your rate for the entire loan term. A temporary buydown reduces your rate only for the first 1-3 years, then reverts to the full rate.

faq.question: Which is better - points or buydown?
faq.answer: Points are better if you'll keep the loan 5+ years. A buydown is better if you plan to refinance soon or need lower initial payments to qualify.
